awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The Identification of Social Systems Trust: Theory and Experimental Validation
awd_abstract_narration:
The effect of social network contacts is generally believed to be much stronger than either advertising or online reputation/rating systems. There are many theoretical models that try to predict how opinions spread among individuals that trust each other, but the experimental evidence to back them quantitatively in a real setting is still elusive. This project aims to close the gap between the theory of opinion diffusion and the several empirical studies that have been made recently on social media data. The novel idea is to exploit the presence of influential nodes that are ?stubborn?, i.e. agents who trust only themselves, to determine how opinions fluctuate in the network as a result of their activities and the relative trust among all agents in the social network. The mathematical insights from the theoretical models of opinion diffusion indicate that stubborn agents excite the social system in such a way that reverberations of their opinions in comments from others can allow one to fit appropriate system equations to this phenomenon. Another key insight is that using steady state models is a more robust method to match real data, since the fluctuations of opinions are not directly observable, only the individual actions and comments are.
 
This effort, if successful, would be akin to realizing a ?social network Radar,? capturing a tomographic image of the hidden medium of a social group mutual trust. Preliminary results in the case of the celebrated linear De Groot's opinion diffusion model applied to Facebook data show remarkably good agreement between the graph one can extract from our method and first-hand knowledge of the group analyzed. This is a high risk high payoff project as several questions still need to be answered and tested to verify the results.

por.por_cntn:
The advent of online social networks (OSNs), such as Facebook and Twitter, has lead to an unprecedented interest in analyzing human behaviors from the “big-data” that the OSNs have generated. Many of the prior works assume an a-priori knowledge of the network structure which is only obtained from crude estimates, such as the friend list on Facebook, without taking into account the relative strength of mutual trusts among social agents.

 

This project developed a suite of mathematical tools for inferring trusts in the social network underlying the set of data collected as opinions of the agents, e.g., the tendency to purchase a new product. Throughout the entire life of this award, three aspects of the inference problem have been covered --- modeling, identification and application to real data. Overall, we have developed a “social radar” which can reliably predict the strength of trusts among social agents as well as the social network structure.

 

The first outcome of this project is to model and analyze the effects of “stubborn” agents, i.e., people whose opinions cannot be influenced by the others.  It is demonstrated that the stubborn agents eventually dominate the opinions in a social network, and their existence can explain about the clustering/polarization phenomena of opinions in OSNs observed in real life. The second outcome is to propose and study a novel social network identification method. Based on the stubborn agent model, an efficient computation method is derived for predicting the trust strengths among the agents. Moreover, given that number of stubborn agents available is at the same order of the average number of friends that an agent has, it is shown that if a large social network can be perfectly identified. In other words, a fundamental limit of social network identifiability from limited data has been proven. Lastly, the “social radar” is applied to a suite of real data. The roll call data from the US Senate is analyzed through fitting a social network model to it. The “influential” Senators (i.e., Senators being trusted by most of the other Senators), e.g., Marco Rubio and Jeff Sessions, predicted by the fitted model coincide with our common sense knowledge about modern US Politics.

 

Departing from the social network applications, the modeling and analysis methods have been extended to studying gene regulatory networks inference. In addition to achieving state-of-the-art performance with the adapted approach, an identifiability condition based on the number of experiments required is proven. This powerful result may serve as a guideline for designing theoretically useful experiments in the future.

 

Being a short-term project, it has partially supported the postdoctoral position of Dr. Xiaoxiao Wu and a PhD student, Mr. Hoi-To Wai, of PI Anna Scaglione. In December 2017, Mr. Hoi-To Wai has successfully defended his dissertation, which has won the ASU Schools of Engineering Dean’s Dissertation Award. The research outcome has been disseminated to various conferences and journals, including a book chapter.
